entities.text: A common criticism of LLM watermarks is they can be removed by AI paraphrasing or human editing.  Let's put this theory to the test! Can a watermark be automatically removed by GPT? Can a grad student do any better? The results surprised me üßµ

First, if you don‚Äôt remember how watermarks work, you might revisit my original post on this issue.
TL;DR The watermark is a subtle pattern embedded in LLM outputs that labels it as machine generated. High accuracy detection usually requires 50-ish words.

The experiment: We generated watermarked text using the Llama model, then asked a non-watermarked LLM (GPT-3.5) to re-write it.  We did lots of prompt engineering to try to get rid of the watermark.  Finally, we checked whether we could detect the watermark in the rewritten text.

Even after AI paraphrasing, we still detect the watermark - BUT we need more text to do it.  Once we observe about 500 tokens (‚âà a half page), we can reliably detect the watermark with a false positive rate of about 1 in a million.

Here‚Äôs why this happened. GPT is statistically likely to recycle word combinations, multi-token long words, and short phrases from the original text. This preserves the watermark in the paraphrased text. But it's been diluted - it takes 10X more tokens to reliably detect it.

Now let‚Äôs see if humans can do any better. We had CS grad students rewrite passages to remove the watermark.  The top performers got $100 coffee shop gift certificates (if you‚Äôve been to grad school you know that both coffee and free stuff are a big deal).  Here‚Äôs the results.

Grad students do better than GPT.  For an average grad student, we need to observe about 1100 tokens (‚âà 1 page) before we can detect the watermark with a 1 in a million error rate.  There‚Äôs quite a bit of variation between people, though.

It seems scrubbing the watermark is tougher than people think. But there‚Äôs some caveats worth mentioning.  Maintaining this much security requires the watermark parameters to be secret, otherwise the attacker knows which ‚Äúgreen‚Äù tokens to remove, which helps scrub the watermark.

Also, removing the watermark is tough but not impossible. A sophisticated actor might have the capability to remove it through (very) meticulous scrubbing or via an LLM with a specialized decoder. Still, many malicious LLMs users are, shall we say, not so sophisticated.

Some people argue that we shouldn't watermark because we can‚Äôt catch everything. I don't like this argument.  In a world with spam, harassment, misinformation, and bots, I‚Äôm ok with stopping some things even if we can‚Äôt catch everything.

++ In your research, what experimental setup or methodology did you employ to test the effectiveness of GPT in automatically removing watermarks from text?

In short, we asked GPT to rewrite a watermarked passage in its own words, then we ran then output through a watermark detector.  We did a lot of prompt engineering to try to break the watermark.  See Appendix A4.

So you end up with an LLM that's highly unlikely to generate tokens from some 20% of its vocab? Have you measured the results with human ratings, not perplexity? What good is a model that can't answer a question with a very specific answer because that answer is in blacklist?

The watermark has negligible impact on the selection of tokens when the model is very confident of its token selection, i.e., it does not prohibit any token from being selected.  Our paper does contain a study of human preferences in Appendix A9.
Have you considered the chance that a human writes the "green" tokens when writing a text, so it is accidentally labeled as machine-generated?
How many false positives do you get? Have you tried to find the watermark in text completely by humans?

Even if watermarking doesn‚Äôt identify every AI-generated text, it can quantitatively compare between different text-generating ‚Äúauthors‚Äù ‚Äî so long as watermarking doesn‚Äôt produce false negatives.

I didn‚Äôt catch if your method was aware of the watermark and testing for it or determining the likelihood of an unknown watermark being present.  Speaks to system implementation.  Is that detailed in the paper?
Your product works very well, but the requirements for the designer's design drafts are a bit high.
Thanks for doing this work. Seems incredibly important to get some empirics on these questions.

I read through your paper, and have some follow up. While the detection of human paraphrasers (p. 8-9) is promising, I also know that simply because someone is a graduate student does not make them a great writer or wordsmith, as evidenced by the fact that
Nice work! And really like your larger body of research.

What if I translate all of my text into Icelandic , then back again into English? Aha your marking of the water not can find investigate myself's works using artifice machines at then point in timeline.
How does the temperature/randomness of the LLM generation correlate to its ability to remove watermarks?

Nice work! I would also attempt to ask GPT to first extract bullet points or tabularise the original text and then rewrite it (in a new context window). I find this approach helpful if I don‚Äôt want GPT to quote verbatim (e.g. for creating new prompts for experiments).

you could and should have paid them for their time directly

not surprising that someone involved in ai exploits human labor for his own profit
This is a really interesting work
. The analysis is very well-synced with our theoretical & empirical findings in
, where we observe the dependence of length and sample complexity.  check

my concern is more that the focus on watermarks plays into the business strategy of LLM platform providers that argue that the only way to make the tech safe is to regulate it so only they can use it, since they can embed watermarks, etc.
I agree. A key consideration is that many bad actors will be producing in volume, which increases the likelihood of catching them!

One approach I‚Äôve heard proposed is to modify the original prompt to ask the model üòÉ to üòÉ insert üòÉ smiliesüòÉ in üòÉ between üòÉeach üòÉ token, then remove the smilies with find/replace. This could defeat watermarking based on next-token probabilities. Think it would work?
Hi! You can find details in Section 4.1 and Appendix A4.
Ah, I see. But wouldn't this only work until community crowd-sources the blacklist by collecting lots of generated text and checking which words occur much rarer compared to their natural frequency?

Hi! To simplify, because the watermark is pseudorandom, the chance that a human will accidentally write N green tokens is equal to N successive coin-flips coming up heads.

We can estimate this probability well, and set thresholds accordingly.

Thanks! Another question: are green tokens non-trivial? For example, "John is a [guy]". The word "guy" is for sure in the whitelist, so it contribute to signal a machine-generate text. Can it happen that this token is green? Trying to understand this from a theoretic perspective

Hi, because of the way the watermark is designed,  we have a tight control over the rate at which humans hit the watermark, we always check against human text.  Check out the ROC curves in Fig.8, or set your own threshold for the z-scores elsewhere in the paper, p=1-cdf(z)

Hi! This is detailed in the paper, we are testing for a watermark that "we" (or rather the entity doing the detection) are aware of. 

We also argue that for a longer context width, a watermark is safer, because it becomes harder for other entities to find the watermark

two of your subjects were detected with only 250 tokens or 200 words while the mean was 800 tokens before detection. I would be very interested in this type of study but with deliberate selection of great graduate student writers.

Perhaps a stratified sample of students who have capabilities at varying levels. My suspicion is, students who come from strong writing backgrounds, and are not just believed to be strong writers because they are graduate students, will take much longer to be detected if at all.

Hi! This is fundamentally not so different from paraphrasing. 
How strong the paraphrase will be depends on the quality of the translation model. A better translation model would be more stable in its back-translation, which would make it easier to detect the watermark.

Interesting approach! How do you get GPT to retain all (or even most) of the content of the original text? In most versions we tried GPT was heavily summarizing the text, and leaving out details. I worry this would be even worse in a 2-phrase approach like this?

For my use case that‚Äôs desired as I want it to make something transformative, with new details. I suppose for trying to remove a watermark it may be problematic if it strays too far from the originally desired content ü§î
) and supports our theoretical and empirical claims
The critical performance measure of the detector is sample complexity (no. of tokens required for detection)!!
I agree - we discuss your paper, which accurately predicts that watermark accuracy recovers with increased token observations, in several spots.

I'm not quite sure I understand the question correctly, what do you define as a whitelist? 

Let's say the context width is 3 and tokenization is [John_ is_ a_ guy]. Then a hash of the first three tokens {John, is, a} determines whether {guy} is green/red.

that might have been from us, we talk about it in previous work (linked further up the thread). We didn't do this attack here because it requires us to reliably get llama/vicuna to follow the cypher(adding üòÉ). 

With longer hash contexts you also need proportionally more üòÄüòÄüòÄ
To simplify, because the watermark is pseudorandom, the chance that a human will accidentally write N tokens of watermarked text is equal to N successive coin-flips coming up heads.

Specifically, if you got some students whose undergrad was English, History, or Philosophy and who are working on master‚Äôs degrees in similar fields, how easy would it be to detect them? All these fields require hundreds of pages of writing throughout their undergrad and

a weaker translation model would be stronger and it would probably take longer to detect the watermark. 

We have code available for our attacks and while evaluation pipeline if you ever want to test this variant :)

and graduate programs. Conversely, a student who comes from an engineering background, the vast majority of the time, has fairly poor writing and limited wordsmithing abilities compared to their liberal arts contemporaries.
Yes, interestingly, watermarking is improving the sample complexity of detection. So the real question is how many tokens observations before we detect...will connect soon to discuss :)
Haha! Thanks. Really appreciate the generous response and feel bad that I was just doing a bit.
